SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

com.ibm.team.repository.common.query
Interface IQuery

All Known Subinterfaces:
IDataQuery, IItemQuery
public interface IQuery

Represents a structured query over items in the Jazz repository.

There are two kinds of queries (and thus two kinds of query results):

  • Item Queries - retrieves a list of item handles based on some filter criteria
  • Data Queries - retrieves a list of data rows, where the individual fields that comprise a row may be values from one or more items, or computed values
Queries are constructed by passing a generated query model to the specialized FACTORY constants, as defined by IItemQuery.FACTORY and IDataQuery.FACTORY. The generated query model provides type-safe members for each path leading to all queryable attributes and references defined on the Jazz component model types. Additionally, the query models and associated members provide type-safe methods that represent query operations that are valid for the given element. For example, an IString represents a String query element, which has a valid operation IString._eq(String). The result of that method creates an IPredicate which tests for equality. Note that all operations available on the model elements are denoted with the leading "_"; this effectively separates the query operation from the queryable model members.

Predicates are used to filter the result set returned by the query. Clients set the predicate using the IQuery.filter(IPredicate) method.

Queries can be executed using the IQueryService.queryData and IQueryService.queryItems service methods.

Since:
0.5
See Also:
IItemQuery, IDataQuery

newStringArg

IStringInputArg newStringArg()
Creates a new input argument slot in this query. The input argument provided when the query is executed must be a String instance and must not be null. The order of the input args passed into the query API must match the order in which the input args were created using the IQuery.new*Arg methods. Input arguments created by this query must only be used in filters for this query.

Returns:
a new String input argument slot for this query.

a new Integer input argument slot for this query.

filter

IQuery filter(IPredicate predicate)
Adds a filter to the requested query to reduce the results returned. Only one filter can be set on an IQuery; extra calls to filter() will replace the current filter. Only selected elements which cause the filter to evaluate to true will be added to the results. To select all teams named "Repo" the following IItemQuery could be used: 
 TeamQueryModel r = TeamQueryModel.ROOT;
 IItemQuery query = IItemQuery.FACTORY.newInstance(r);
 query.filter(r.name()._eq("Repo"));
The predicate must be based on the same query model root that this query instance is based on. The following code is invalid because the query is based on TeamQueryModel and the filter is based on ContributorQueryModel: 
 IItemQuery query = IItemQuery.FACTORY.newInstance(TeamQueryModel.ROOT);
 query.filter(ContributorQueryModel.ROOT.name()._eq("Matt"));

Parameters:
predicate - the predicate used to filter results
Returns:
this query instance with a filter applied

isSameQuery

boolean isSameQuery(IQuery query)
Returns whether the given query is the same as this query.

Parameters:
query - a query to compare this query against
Returns:
true if the queries are the same, false if they are different.

getResultLimit

int getResultLimit()
Returns the limit on the number of rows that this query will generate. If there is no limit, then 0 will be returned.

Returns:
the limit

setResultLimit

void setResultLimit(int resultLimit)
Sets the value of the resultLimit attribute. Negative values are not permitted.

Clients are advised to set a result limit if it is not reasonable to handle unlimited results. For example, if displaying to a user the results of a query, it may not make sense to display more than a few pages worth of results because most users won't want to see more than that. This does generally require a strategy to get additional pages for those few situations where more results are requested. For example, by sorting the results, it is possible to re-run the query with a filter that excludes the already presented results, and thus get the next page(s) of results.

Parameters:
resultLimit - the new value of the resultLimit attribute.

getMaxQueryTime

int getMaxQueryTime()
Returns the maximum amount of time, in milliseconds, that this query will execute before being canceled.

Returns:
the time, in milliseconds, that the query will execute for or -1 if the query will execute forever.

setMaxQueryTime

void setMaxQueryTime(int timeInMilliseconds)
Sets the maximum amount of time that the caller would like this query to execute for. The time given will be handled with a best effort by the database. It's possible that some databases might not support cancellation after a specific amount of time.

Parameters:
timeInMilliseconds - the maximum time, in milliseconds, that this query should execute before being canceled.
See Also:
IQuery.getMaxQueryTime()
